intro: Acer nigrum var. schneckii, commonly known as the black maple, is a deciduous tree native to eastern North America. It is characterized by its dark green, palmately lobed leaves that turn vibrant shades of red and orange in autumn. The tree produces small, yellowish-green flowers in early spring, followed by winged seeds called samaras. It typically grows to a height of 20–30 meters and thrives in moist, well-drained soils. This variety is often cultivated for its ornamental value and is relatively hardy in temperate climates.
